Glottolog.Name: nort2943
FunctionAP: syntactic pivot; deemphasize patient; but also atelic (Ngali 2006: 134)
Polysemy: kliq is syncretic (inceptive aspect); tnik and kliq function also as adversative (Nagai 2006: 134)
Source: Lanz, Linda A. 2010. A grammar of Iñupiaq morphosyntax. Houston: Rice University doctoral dissertation. Nagai, Tadataka. 2006. Agentive and patientive verb bases in North Alaskan Iñupiaq. Doctoral dissertation, University of Alaska Fairbanks.
Comments: *the author does not discuss the omission of the P in the AP, but all the provided examples contain oblique P./ ** the split concerns of whether the input verb takes agentive or patientve subject argument. Inupiaq verbal stems are divided into two groups: (i) agentive verbal stems have the intransitive subject corresponding with the transitive subject; (ii) patientive verbs are those which “have the intransitive subject corresponding with the transitive object” . Thus the S of an agentive verb is agent, and S of a patientive verb is patient. Agentive verbs take zero antipassive marker vs. patientive verbs that take an explcit AP marker. /*** I mark '2 Type' where Type 1 refers to the AP without AP marker, and Type 2 involves the AP clause with AP marker.
